title: Quiz 1: Foundations of Education & Learning Principles
topicName: Health Education Unit Five: Teaching and Learning Methodologies
description: Assess your understanding of the historical background of education in Kenya, core principles of learning, and key learning theories.

questions.question: Which post-independence commission was established in 1964 with the primary aim of improving education to fight ignorance, disease, and poverty in Kenya?
questions.explanation: The Ominde Report (1964) was the first commission set up after independence to guide education policy towards fighting ignorance, disease, and poverty.
questions.hint: Think of the very first commission after independence.

questions.question: The art and science of helping adults learn is referred to as ___BLANK___, whereas the art of helping children learn is known as ___BLANK___.
questions.explanation: Andragogy focuses on adult learning principles (self-directed, experience-based), while pedagogy traditionally focuses on child learning (teacher-directed).
questions.hint: One starts with 'A' for adults, the other with 'P' for paediatrics/children.

questions.question: According to Bloom's Taxonomy, which of the following are the three primary domains of learning? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Benjamin Bloom identified three domains: Cognitive (knowledge), Affective (attitudes/feelings), and Psychomotor (skills).

questions.question: In the cognitive theory of learning, 'learning' is viewed primarily as a change in observable behaviour caused by external reinforcement.
questions.explanation: This describes Behaviourist theory (like Skinner's). Cognitive theories focus on internal mental processes: how knowledge is acquired, stored, and retrieved.
questions.hint: Does cognitive theory focus on the 'mind' or just 'behaviour'?

questions.question: Match the learning theorist with their key contribution or concept:
questions.explanation: Skinner = Behaviourism/Rewards; Rogers = Humanism/Student-centred; Bruner = Discovery/Problem solving; Ausubel = Linking new info to existing knowledge.
questions.hint: Skinner worked with pigeons (behaviour); Rogers focused on the person (humanism).

questions.question: What is the term for a learning approach where the teacher provides problems and resources, allowing the learner to solve them independently?
questions.explanation: Discovery learning, championed by Bruner, encourages learners to use their own insights and available resources to solve problems.

questions.question:
Read the scenario below. Which principle of learning is BEST illustrated?

'A nursing student first learns to take a manual blood pressure on a fellow student. Later, she practices on patients in the ward. Finally, she is able to interpret BP readings in complex clinical cases.'

richContent.content: Scenario: Progression from simple peer practice to complex clinical application.

options.text: Learning evolves from competence through repetition and moves from simple to complex
Learning only occurs through negative reinforcement
Learning is unrelated to past experience

questions.explanation: This illustrates the principle that learning is gradual, moves from simple to complex (known to unknown), and is reinforced by practice/repetition.
questions.hint: Focus on the progression and practice aspect.

questions.question: Arrange the following nursing qualifications in the chronological order of their historical emergence in Kenya:
questions.explanation: Historical order: Ordinance (1949) -> KRN (1952) -> KEN (1959) -> KRCHN (1987).
questions.hint: The Ordinance established the framework first; Community Health Nursing came much later.

questions.question: Which of the following conditions make an environment CONDUCIVE to learning? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Makes the individual feel respected and accepted

questions.explanation: A conducive environment is supportive, safe for making mistakes, respectful, and encourages active participation and cooperation.
questions.hint: Think about where YOU would feel most comfortable learning.

questions.question: Review the table below comparing Adult and Child Learning. Which row contains an ERROR?

richContent.content:
FeatureAdult Learning (Andragogy)Child Learning (Pedagogy)
ASelf-conceptSelf-directedDependent
BExperienceRich resource for learningLittle experience to draw on
CReadinessDevelops from life tasks/problemsBiologically/academically determined
DOrientationSubject-centredProblem-centred

questions.explanation: Row D is incorrect because Adult learning is typically PROBLEM-centred (or life-centred), while Child learning is SUBJECT-centred.
questions.hint: Check the 'Orientation' row carefully. Do adults learn subjects for the sake of it, or to solve problems?
